And once blown down; not missed, but for ever lost.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Out crocodile, —

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: You will not murder me!

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I'll cure you of the Kings evil. —

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: To one woman
Another should be pitiful, hear me speak?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: How dares so base a flower follow my sun
At's rising to his setting.

sp.speaker: Torm.
sp.l: I follow none.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: How dar'st thou serpent wind about a tree
That's mine.

sp.speaker: Torm.
sp.l: I do not.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Or to shake the leaves.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: By heaven, not any.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Or once to taste the fruit
though thrown into thy lap, if from a harlot
Prayers ever came; pray, for thou diest.

sp.speaker: Torm.
sp.l: Then kill me.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: How did my husband win thee?

sp.speaker: Torm.
sp.l: By mere force; a bawd betrayed me to him.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Worse and worse.

sp.speaker: Torm.
sp.l: If ever I have wronged your royal bed
In act, in thought, nail me for ever fast,
To scape this tiger of the Kings fierce lust
I will do any thing, I will speak treason
Or drink a cup of poison, which may blast
My enticing face, and make it leprous foul:
Ruin you all this, so you keep up my soul;
That's all the wealth I care for.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I have now no heart left to kill thee, rise, thou and I
Will like two quarrelling gallants faster tie
A knot of love, we both i'th field being wounded
Since we must needs be sharers, use me kindly
And play not the right citizen, to undo
Your partner, who ith' stock has more than you.
sp.stage: A noise within. Enter the King.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Must you be closeted?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What are you doing?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Not getting children.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Naked knives; for what,
Speak, 'sdeath speak you.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: They both fell from her side.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You lie, away.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Must you be closeted?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: When heart breakest thou, thou dost too much swell,
This aspish biting, is incurable.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Be true to me I charge you, did the Queen
offer no violence to you.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: None at all.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Why were these drawn,

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: I know not.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Know not; what's here,
Why is this rose denied with a pearled tear.
When the sunshines so warm, you know not that too,
The lamb has amed the lion, the vulture tears
Upon the eagle's heart, these subtle wires
Chanie Jove, these balls, from whose flames Cupid drew,
His wild fire burns here, this you know not too.
I love you, that you know not neither, you're coy,
And proud, and fair, you know this,

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: I beseech you
Let me shake off the golden fetters you tie
About my body, you enjoy a body
Without a soul, for I am now not here.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Where then.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: At home in my poor husband's arms,
This is your court, that mine.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Your husband's arms,
Thou art his whore, he played the thief and robbed
Another of thee, and to spoil the spoiler,
Is kingly justice, 'tis a lawful prize
That's taken from pirates; there's are fellow wives.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Which of your subjects (Which abroad adore
Your state, your greatness, presence and your throne
Of sun beams) think you now are with a wanton,
Or working a chaste wife to become one.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I work thee not to be so, for when time
Shall jog his glass and make those sands lie low
Which now are at the top, thyself shalt grow
In self same place my Queen does.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: What tree ever stood
Long and deep rooted, that was set in blood;
I will not be your whore to wear your crown.
Nor call any King my husband, but mine own.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No!

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: No 'twere shame amongst all our city dames
If one could not scape free, their blasted fames.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The sound of bells and timbrels make you mad
As it does a tiger, the softer that I stroke you
The worse you bite, your father and your husband
Are at my sending come to court, I'll lay
Honours on both their backs, here they shall stay
Because I'll keep you here, if you do frown
The engine which rears up, shall pluck all down.
I'll fetch 'em to you myself.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: O who can stifling scape in baser throngs,
When princes courts threaten the selfsame wrongs!

sp.stage: Flourish. Enter King, Malevento, Cordolente, Jago, Alphonso, Gazetto, and Tormiella.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You've the best welcome which the court can yield,
For the King gives it you.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Your grace is gracious.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Is this your father?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: My proper flesh and blood sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And that your husband?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Not I sir; I married an honest wench that went in a cap, no whim-whams ; I did but shuffle the first dealing, you cut last, and dealt last, by the same token you turned up a court card.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Is the man jealous!

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: No, but a little troubled with the yellow jaundice, and you know if it get to the crown of the head, a man's gone.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: We send not for you hither to be braved,
Sirrah cast your darts elsewhere .

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Amongst the wild Irish sir hereafter.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: 'Tis our Queen's pleasure that your wife be called
Her woman, and because she will not lose her,
She hath importuned us to raise you both;
Your name sir?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Mine, Andrada Malevento.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Andrada Malevento we make you
Vice-admiral of our navy.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: O spiteful comedy, he's not a courtier of half an hours standing, and he's made a vice already.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: We make thy husband —

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: A cuckold do you not.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Son you forget yourself.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Meddle with your own office; there's one will look that none meddles with mine.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Is not a change good?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Yes, of a lousy shirt.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Take hence that fellow, he's mad.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I am indeed horn-mad, o me, in the holiest place of the kingdom have I caught my undoing, the church gave me my bane.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: What the church gave thee, thou hast still.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Half parts, I thought one had ta'en thee up.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Take me home with thee, I'll not stay here.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Let me not come to court.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: The King is vexed, let me persuade thee son
To wink at small faults.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: What sir Pandarus!

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Sends the King you to blush in's room.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: You're a baggage.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Go tell the lunatic so; Andrada hark,

sp.speaker: Jag.
sp.l: The King sir bids me sing into your ear,
Sweet notes of place and office which shall fall —

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Into my mouth, I gape for 'em.

sp.speaker: Jag.
sp.l: He bids me ask what will content you.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Nothing, nothing, why sir the powers above cannot please us, and can Kings think you, when we are brought forth to the world, we cry and bawl as if we were unwilling to be born; and when we are a dying we are mad at that.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Take hence that wolf that barks thus.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I am muzzled, but one word with your majesty, I am sober sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: So sir.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: You oft call parliaments, and there enact
Laws good and wholesome, such as who so break
Are hung by th' purse or neck, but as the weak
And smaller flies i'th spider's web are ta'en
When great ones tear the web, and free remain.
So may that moral tale of you be told,
Which once the wolf related: in the fold
The shepherds killed a sheep and eat him there
The wolf looked in, and seeing them at such cheer,
Alas (Quoth he) should I touch the least part
Of what you tear, you would pluck our my heart,
Great men make laws, that whosoever draws blood
Shall die, but if they murder flocks 'tis good:
I'll go eat my lamb at home sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Part, and thus reckon never to see her more.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Never!

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Never thus, but thus a prince's whore.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Thou dar'st not, if thou dost; my heart is great,
Thus wronged, thou canst do little if not threat.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: At what dost-laugh?

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: At a thing of nothing, at thee; why shouldst thou be afraid to fall into the cuckold's disease.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Because it makes a doctor an ass, nothing can cure it, are you answered sir?

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: Come thou'rt a fool, to grieve that thy wife is taken away by the King to his private bedchamber,
sp.l: Now like a book called in, she'll sell better than ever she did.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Right sir, but could he choose no stock to graft upon, but that which was planted in my nursery.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: I'll show thee a reason for that.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: Lechers coming to women, are like mice amongst many cheeses, they taste every one, but feed upon the best: horns rightly weighed are nothing.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: How nothing! o sir, the smallest letters hurt your eyes most, and the least headache which comes by a woman's knocking hurts more than a cut to the scull by a man's knocking.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Yet I warrant thou dar'st swear the party's honest?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Ha; swear; not I, no man durst ever swear for his wife but Adam, nor any woman for her husband but Eve, fare you well sir.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Whether art flying?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: In pieces dost not see I'm shot out of a cannon.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Downwards I'll shoot thee, but as devil's use
I'll tickle at thy tortures, dance at thy stumbling,
Play with thee, and then paw thee, 'Shalt make me merry
The crown of black deeds that are hatched in hell
Is to outlive and laugh, and all's played well.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: I have not passed by a don, to touch whose hand mine own was never more troubled with a more terrible itch.

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.p: I have not met a signior, at whom mine own eyes (As if roasted enough) did ever burn more in desire to fly out: so that whether to recoil or advance on, I am between hawk and buzzard.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: The honey of sweet compliment so turn up your tusks or mochatoes, that they be not too stiff, to bristle against my acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.p: Your acquaintance is a limbeck, out of which runneth a perfumed water, bathing my nostrils in a strong scent of your embracings: are you of court signior?

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.l: No signior of the city: are you a don of the city!

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.l: No signior of the court city, I smile,

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.l: Why.

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.p: I assure you signior, you are to us of the court but animals you are held but as shooing horns to wait on great lords heels.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Let 'em pay us what they owe then, and pull on their shoes, and we'll wait no more.

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.l: You are our apes.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.l: But you are fuller of apish-tricks.

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.p: No sooner leap our ladies into a fashion, but your wives are ready to creep into the same.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Why not; for though some of your ladies invent the fashion, some of our wives husbands are never paid for the stuff or making.

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.p: Give way with your poor scull to our oars: for I tell thee signior you of the city, are the flatten milk of the kingdom, and we of the court, the cream.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: I tell thee signior! we of the city eat none of your court butter, but some of your munch up our flatten milk cheese.

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.p: Be not too loud; though you are good ringers in the city, for most of you have bells at your doors.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Be not you too loud: for you might be good singers at court but that most of you are spoilt in learning your pricksong.

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.p: Be temperate: I will show you your city cinquepace, you bear, swear, tear, rear, and wear; you bear the tankard, swear shop oaths, tear money out of debtors throats, rear rich estates, wear good clothes, but carry your conscience in torn pockets.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Be attentive, I will show you your court coranto pace, it consisteth of 5. bees and 3. cees; you borrow of any man, are brave on any terms, brag at any hand to pay, bellow at any that demands it, bite any catchpole that fangs you, but carry neither conscience nor coin in your whole pockets.

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.p:
Tell me signior, tell me why in the city does a
harmless sign hang at the door of a subtle Nicodemus sitting in a shop?

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: And tell me signior, tell me, why when you eat our good cheer i'th city, have you handsome wide chops, but meeting us at court, none; your gum's glued up, your lips coped like a ferret, not so much as the corner of a custard; if a cold cup, and a dry cheat loaf 'tis well.

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.p: Come, come, you are acorns, and your sons the prodigals that eat you up.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Go, go, you are prodigals, and glad of the yellow acorns we leave our sons.

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.p: I will cross myself when I owe money to a citizen, and pass by his door.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: I will bless myself, when a courtier owing me no money, comes near my door.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: You are descended from the tankard generation.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: You are ascended up to what you are, from the black Jack and bombard distillation.

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.l: Dear signior.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.l: Delicious don.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Boy.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Art sure thou sawest the admiral at court!

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.l: Am I sure I see your lordship in your gown.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: And talking with the King?

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.l: Most familiarly.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: And what say the people about my committing to mine own house?

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.l: The beast grins at it, there's a libel already of you my lord.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: A libel, away.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Yes faith my lord, and a song to the tune of lament ladies, lament.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: I'm glad the stinkards are so merry, a halter on 'em, it's music to them to have every man thrown off, you have seen the King's mistress, boy have you not, what manner of piece is't?

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: Troth my lord I know not, I never saw her shot off, a pretty little pocket dag.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: What report gives she?

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: A very good report of her husband, but he gives an ill report of her.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: How does the ladies take it; now the King keeps a
Wench under the Queen's nose?

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: They take it passing heavily, it goes to the heart of some of them, that he keeps not them too.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: I heard say they were all once leaving the court?

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.l: True sir, but there was a device which stopped 'em.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Who are you!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My lord, we must speak with you.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: What are you? fetch me a weapon

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Your friends.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: 'Sdeath break it open.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: The King; I did not understand your majesty.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You shall, for I'll speak plain to you, know you these?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You do not, a King's arm thou seest
Has a long reach, as far as Portugal
Can we fetch treason back hatched here by you.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Me!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thee and the traitorous Portugals to deprive me
Of life and crown, but I shall strike their King
And them, and thee beneath into the earth.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: And lower than earth you cannot.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Half your body is in the grave, it only lacks our hand
To cast the dust upon you, yet you stand
On slippery ice yourself, and trip at us
Whose foot is fixed on rocks, but since thou'st, thrown
Thyself down never look to rise.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: I care not, I will be little so in debt to you, that I will not owe you so much as God a mercy for my life.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You shall not then, stand not to aim at marks
Now rove not but make choice of one fair white
thou'st but one arrow to shoot, and that's thy flight
The admiral knows our pleasure.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: And heaven knows mine
Left in mine enemy's hand, are you my jailor?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No my lord, I think I'm rather left
To be your confessor.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: I need not any,
That you and I should both meet at one ball,
I being the stronger, yet you give the fall.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: A kind of football slight, my lord, men use
Exceeding much at court, yourself has heard
Little shrimps have thrown men higher than the guard;
But barring this rough play, let's now consider,
For what I stay, and what you are to do.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Do what?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: To die.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: And must you play the hangman.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Break in fellows.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: 'Sdeath what are these?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Your executioners appointed by the King.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: These my executioners,
And you my overseer; wherefore kneel they?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: To beg your pardon, for they fear their work
Will never please you.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: What book's that they hold
This is no time for dedications.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: That book is sent in love to you from the King
It contains pictures of strange sundry deaths
He bids you choose the easiest.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Then I choose this.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Your choice is ill made.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: I'm more sorry sir,
I had rather have my body hacked with wounds,
then t'have a hangman fillip me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My lord pray pardon me
I'm forced to what I do, 'tis the King's pleasure
To have you die in private.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Anywhere
Since I must down, the King might let me fall
From lofty pinnacles, to make my way
Through an armed field, yet for all that, even then
Unless I slew a kingdom full of men
I should at last be paid home: blackest fate
Thy worst, I here defy thee, what the state
Appoints 'tis welcome.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: That's to have your head.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: 'Tis ready.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: He'll be quiet when you are dead.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Madam there's a fellow stays without to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: With me!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Your shoemaker I think.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Hast brought my shoes?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Yes madam.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: You drew them not on last.

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: No madam, my master that served you last has very good custom, and deals with other ladies as well as you, but I have fitted you before now, I should know the length of your foot.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: I do not remember thee.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I'm sorry you have forgotten me.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: What shoe was the last you drew on?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: A yellow.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: A yellow! I never wore that colour.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Yes madam by that token when I fitted you first, you wore not your shoes so high i'th instep, but methinks you now go clean awry.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: A fault I cannot help, many ladies besides me go so,
I hope 'twill grow to a fashion ..

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Has not that fellow done there?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Yes sir, I have now done, I have a suit to you madam, that none may be your shoemaker but I.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Thy master thou sayst serves me, I should wrong him then.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Yet do you me more wrong, o my Tormiella!
Is the leaf torn out where our love was writ,
That I am quite forgotten!

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Softly good sweet.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: O misery, I make myself a thief,
To steal mine own, another at my fire
Sits whiles I shake with cold, I fatten a stranger,
And starve myself.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Danger throws eyes upon thee,
Thus visit me, watch time for my escape
To any country, by thy dearest side
I'll lackey all the world o'er, I'll not change
Thee for a thousand Kings; there's gold.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Not yet done?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Yes sir, I'm only taking instructions to make her a lower chopine, she finds fault that she's lifted too high.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: The more fool she.

sp.speaker: Jag.
sp.l: The King comes madam, he inquires for you.
sp.stage: Enter King, Valasco, Gazetto, and others.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My brother John is gone then?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I ha' bestowed him as you commanded, in's grave.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: He's best there,
Except the gods, Kings love none whom they fear.
How now!

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: My shoemaker.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O haste fitted her, so, hence sir.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: As a worm on my belly, what should the ant,
On his poor molehill brave the elephant,
No, signior no,
No brains to stay, but saves a head to go.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Let me have no more of this: have not we eyes
pointed like sunbeams, go to, get you in.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Angel from heaven, fallen a King's concubine.

sp.speaker: Marti nes
sp.l: May it please your grace,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Marti nes
sp.l: Her highness drowned in sorrow, that your brow
Has been so long contracted into frowns,
Wishing to die unless she see it smoothed,
Commends her best love to you in this jewel
The image of her heart.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My lord admiral, my wife's grown kind, see!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: One of the happiest hours
Mine age e'er numbered; would your highness now
Would fetch up the red blood her cheeks hath lost
By sending her, some symbol of your love.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Pray step yourself unto her, say I lock
My heart up in your bosom to her use, and give it her

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I'll lend it in your name.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Do.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: She shall pay her heart for it in interest.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I'll see her anon
Leave us, stay you, and set that table here.
A chair, none trouble us, do you serve the Queen?

sp.speaker: Marti nes
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: We know you now, you're in our eye
Are the doors fast?

sp.speaker: Marti nes
sp.l: They are sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Nearer yet,
Do not you know of a conspiracy,
To take away my life upon saint — tush,
No matter for the day, you know the plot sir?

sp.speaker: Marti nes
sp.l: By heaven I know of none!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Blushing do you stain?

sp.speaker: Marti nes
sp.l: It is not guilt but anger.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You've all fixed
Your hands and seals to an indenture drawn
By such a day to kill me.

sp.speaker: Marti nes
sp.l: For my part
My loyalty like a rough diamond shines
The more 'tis cut, I have no hand in that
Or any baseness else against your life
Or kingdom.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No!

sp.speaker: Marti nes
sp.l: None.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Fetch me ink and paper
I soon shall try that, come sir write your name:
Stay, your own words shall choke you, 'twas a letter
Wrapped up in hidden characters, and sent
Enclosed in a pomegranate, to a great don
And thus subscribed: at your pleasure your obsequious vassal
Write this, and then your name, here.

sp.speaker: Marti nes
sp.l: At your pleasure.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thy hand shakes.

sp.speaker: Marti nes
sp.l: No sir, your obsequious vassal.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Here sir, your name now there so low it stood.

sp.speaker: Marti nes
sp.l: Martin's Cazalla de Barameda.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: There's in thy face no traitor I cannot tell
Good mouths have given thee to me, on your life
Be not you like a wolves-skin drum to fright
The whole heard by your sound, I will compare
Your hand with this, that's all, but sir beware
You prate to none of what 'twixt us is passed.

sp.speaker: Marti nes
sp.l: Were I i'th world above, I would desire
To come from thence, to give that man the lie,
That once should dare to blot my loyalty.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Here take this key, meet me some half hour hence i'th privy gallery with two naked poniards.

sp.speaker: Marti nes
sp.l: Two poniards.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Yes, go send somebody in, stay, Lupo
Can you write?

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Indite a letter — 'sdeath sir — here begin

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: After my hearty commendations, so sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How! write — my most admired mistress.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Mired mistress,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: With the fire you first kindled in me, still I am burned.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Still I am burned:

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: So that thunder shall not hinder me from climbing the highest step of the ladder.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Climbing the highest step of the ladder.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Of your perfections, though I be confounded for ever.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Be confounded for ever.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Your high pleasures are mine, mine yours.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Mine yours.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And I die ever lastingly until I be in your bosom.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: And I die — until I be in your bosom.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: So.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: So.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Hold.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Here sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Where are the gentlemen of our chamber?

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Without sir?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Bid them attend us close.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: I shall.

sp.speaker: Marti nes
sp.l: Would this days work were done, I do not like
To see a bull to a wild figtree tied
To make him tame, beasts licking 'gainst the hair
Foreshow some storm, and I foresee some snare:
His sword is dipped in oil, yet does it wound
Deadly, yet stand it, innocence wronged is crowned.
sp.stage: Enter the King, Alphonso, and Gazetto.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Treason!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Kill the villain.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Stay, none touch him
On your lives; on King's shoulders stand
The heads of the colossy of the gods
(Above the reach of traitors) were the beds
of twenty thousand snakes laid in this bosom,
There's thunder in our looks to break them all,
Leave us.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: You are too venturous.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Jove cannot fall,
Both person place and business were quite lost
Out of our memory, lay aside these poniards
We have altered now our business, you shall bear sir
Our salutation to the Queen — not sealed!
'Sfoot, nor endorsed! some ink, come let the forehead
Have no more wrinkles in't-but this, to the Queen,
Write it.

sp.speaker: Marti nes
sp.l: To the Queen, no more!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No, no, 'tis well,
Hast thou no seal about thee? if my wife
Exceptions take missing our royal signet
Say that not having that, I borrowed yours.

sp.speaker: Marti nes
sp.l: I shall sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Hide it, go without there.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You met him did you not, how looked the slave?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Most strangely.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Unparalleled villain! Devil's could not set
To hatch such spiteful mischief, guard me closely,
When you see him at the stake then worry him,
Are all weaponed?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: All, all.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: When darts invisible do fly,
A slave may kill a lion in the eye.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Who gave you this?

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: A gentleman of your chamber.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Call in the villain,
Thou audacious serpent!
How dar'st thou wind in knotted curls thy lust
About our honour; where hadst thou this letter?

sp.speaker: Marti nes
sp.l: I had it from the King.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Out impudent traitor.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How now at barleybreak, who are in hell?
What's that? to the Queen, what Queen!

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Me, 'tis to me
Your mistress there the messenger, her secretary
He here.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Uds death.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Your trull and he have laid
Trains to blow up mine honour, I am betrayed.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Lupo, fasten her.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Fasten me!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Jago see.
Look all, bind fast this devil, is there no circle
To be damned in but mine.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Slave let me go.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O thou lustful harlot.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Guard me heaven.

sp.speaker: Marti nes
sp.l: I'm sold.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Thou villain speak truth.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Keep her off.

sp.speaker: Marti nes
sp.l: Most basely.
Betrayed and baffled, is that letter the same
I sent in to the Queen.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: The very same.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Is this thy hand?

sp.speaker: Marti nes
sp.l: 'Tis sir, but hear me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And this thy name, thy hand?

sp.speaker: Marti nes
sp.l: My name, my hand.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Save him and let him spit
His blackest poison forth?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Spare him, unhand her.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Let me have justice as thou art a King!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: To prison with them both.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: As I am thy wife
Make not thyself a strumpet of me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Hence, guard her.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I come heaven, guarded with innocence.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Follow your mistress, you.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Yes, to her grave.
O that I now were swallowed in some wave.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O that I
Should in a woman's lap my kingdom lay,
Honour and life, and she should all betray
To a groom, a slave.

sp.speaker: Jag.
sp.l: Let not her poison run
Too near your heart.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Jago I have done,
Pray let my grief want company, this wrack
So great, shall make th'whole kingdom mourn in black.
Lupo!

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Did your highness call!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Yes, hark thee Lupo:
It may be thou'rt a serpent dull of sight,
Be quick of hearing, may be thou'rt a hare
And canst see sideways, let me lock up here,
What ever's laid in there.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: I am strongly charmed.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Wilt venture for me?

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: To the threshold of hell.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: May I trust thee?

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Else employ me not.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Didst ever kill a scorpion?

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Never, I ha' been stung by one.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Didst never bait a wild bull?

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: That's the pastime I most love and follow.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: A strange disease
hangs on me, and our doctors say the blood
Only of these two beasts must do me good,
Darest thou attempt to kill them?

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Were they devils
With heads of iron, and claws jointed with brass,
Encounter them I shall, in what park run they?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The Queen that scorpion is, Tormiella's husband
The mad ox broken loose; in a small volume
What mischief may be writ, in a maze!

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: No, in a muse,
I'm plotting how to do't, and to come off.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: This does it, by this key burst up all doors
That can betray thee, done be sure to rise,
Let a King's royal breath, send the hence flying.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: As powder does the bullet.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Heaped up honours
Are scedules to thine enterprise annexed,
Do it and mount —

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: To th'gallows.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thyself goes next.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: I scorn to be thy blood hound
Why should I vex a soul did never grieve me?
The Queen an honest lady: should I kill her,
It were as if I pulled a temple down,
And from the ruins of that built up a stews,
She lives, but butcher like the ox I'll use.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: O royal sir, my daughter Tormiella
Has lost her use of reason and run mad.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: When!

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Not half an hour since.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Mad now! now frantic!
When all my hopes are at their highest pitch
T'enjoy her beauties! talk no more: thou liest.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: May it please your majesty -

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Curses consume thee — on —

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: It is dispatched, the Queen is lost, never to be found.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Wave upon wave,
Hard hearted furies, when will you dig my grave:
You do not hear him, thunder shakes heaven first
Before dull earth can feel it:
My dear, dearest Queen is dead.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: The Queen dead!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What said she last!

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Commend me to the King
And tell him this, mine honour is not wracked,
Though his love be.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And so her heartstrings cracked!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Some trick upon my life, state-conjuring
To raise up devils in prisons, and i'th dark:
If she be dead, I'll see her.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Villainous man,
Thou see what we have enjoyed, thou impudent fool
away, Jago give this tumbling whale
Empty barrels to play with, till this troublous seas
(Which he more raging makes) good heaven appease.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Well, I say nothing, birds in cages mourn
At first, but at last sing; I will take my turn.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My Queen dead, I shall now have rhyming slaves
Libel upon us, giving her innocent wings
But say we murdered her, scandal dare strike Kings:
Then here's another moon of Spain eclipsed,
One whom our best loved Queen put in her bosom,
For sweetness of pure life, integrity,
And (In court beauties wondrous) honesty,
She's mad too, Lupo, Tormiella's mad!

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Mad!

sp.speaker: Jag.
sp.l: As a march whore.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Mad, shall I work upon her?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Use thy skill.

sp.speaker: Jag.
sp.l: I would to heaven your highness —

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ha! the Queen! was she not at my elbow?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Here was nothing.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I must not live thus, Jago if I lie
After the kingly fashion without a woman
I shall run mad at midnight; I will marry
The lunatic lady, she shall be my Queen,
Proclaim her so.

sp.speaker: Jag.
sp.l: Your highness does but jest!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: All the world's frantic, mad with mad are best.

sp.speaker: Iag.
sp.l: Wretched state of Kings, that standing high,
Their faults are marks, shot at by every eye.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: Give me the key, make all fast, leave us, I'll screw her wits to the right place.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Apollo bless thee.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Are not you a woollen-draper?

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Whether is a woman's life measured by the ell or the yard.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: All women by the yard sure, it's no life else.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: I'm now near seventeen years old, if I should die at these years, am I not a fool.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: Yes marry are you, for the law allows none to be of discretion, till they come to twenty one.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: Out upon you, you are a lawyer, pray get you hence, for you'll not leave me clothes to my back if I keep you company, I'm mad enough now, and you'll make me stark mad.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: I am not what I seem, no doctor I
But by your husband sent in this disguise
To sound your bosom.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: You bob for eels, do you not?

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Here has he locked his mind up, but for me
To put a burning linstock in a hand
That may give fire, and send my soul in powder,
I know not, pardon me, fare you well lady.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Hist do you hear?

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: The eyes of mercy guard thee
Were't known for what I ventured thus, 'twere death,
I'll to your husband.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Stay, I am not mad
Yet I have cause to rave, my wits like bells
Are backward rung, only to fright the tyrant
That whilst his wild lust wanders, I may fly
To my sweet husband's arms, here I have hid
The trains I mean to lay for mine escape.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Excellent, he shall second you.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Should any watch us!

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: All's fast, run mad again then, the King thinks
Me some rare fellow, you shall leave the court
Now if you'll taste my counsel.

sp.speaker: Torm.
sp.l: I'll drink gall to cure me of this sickness.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Sit then down here
I'll bind you fast because it shall appear,
That you grow worse and worse, then will I tell
The King, the only course to leave you well,
Is to remove you home to mine own lodging,
I'll bind you.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: For ever to thee.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Once hence, you may fly
To th' straits, and then cross o'er to Barbary:
So, th' art a strumpet.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: What's that you speak!

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: A damned one;
Dost thou not know me! I am Gazetto!

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Mercy.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Who like a ball of wildfire have been tossed
To make others sport, but here I burst and kill:
A perjured strumpet.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: I am none,
My father swore that I should marry thee,
And then a tiger and a lamb had met,
I never was thine, nor ever will be.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Swear thou art not mine,
That when I see thy heart drunk with hot oaths,
This fiend may pitch thee reeling into hell,
Swear that thou art not mine.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: By heaven I am not,
To prove I swear right to thee, change that weapon,
See at my girdle hang my wedding knives,
With those dispatch me.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: To th' heart?

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Aim right I beseech thee.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: I'll not kill thee now for spite
Because thou beg'st it.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Then good villain spare me!

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Neither, here's that shall sink thee; to the King
Thy juggling and these letters shall be shown.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Upon thy head be my confusion
The King! I shall both feed his rage and lust,
First doom me to any tortures!

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Thou shalt then swear —
Because I know he'll force the tie a knot,
The church must see and sigh at, if he marries thee,
Swear when he comes to touch thy naked side,
To bury him in those sheets, thou art his bride.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: By heaven that night's his last, my just heart keeps
This vow graven there.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Till then my vengeance sleeps,
Where is the King?

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: I have refined
That chaos which confounded her fair mind.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Move in thy voice the spheres, when next thou speakst, Tormiella.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: I am well my fearful dream
Is vanished, thanks to heaven and that good man.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thou givest me another crown, o Vindicados,
The axletree on which my kingdom moves,
Leans on thy shoulders, I am all thine; Tormiella!
Bright Cynthia look not pale, Endymion's here,
Hymen shall fetch a leap from heaven t'alight
Full in thine arms, back thou black ominous night.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Signior Lupo, why don, not know me, I am the poor shopkeeper, whose ware is taken up by the King.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: You lie.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: True, as judges do with their wives, very seldom, I am Cordolente a poor gudgeon diving thus under water, to see how Neptune and his mermaids swim together, but dare not come near him, for fear he sets dogfish to devour me.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: An excellent mask against the marriage, now get a private coat, the King means to have you stabbed.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: He does that already, with the bodkin that sticks in my wife's hair.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: He has not the patience to stay the dressing of his meat of thy providing, he will have it taken up, and eat the flesh raw, he will be married incontinently.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Will she set her hands to my horns?

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: Yes, and set them to your head, she follows the steps of her old grandam, all evils take their names from her, the ills of Eve, thy wife for the hoop ring thou marriedst her withal, hath sworn to send thee a death's head.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Sworn!

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: Sworn, were thy case my case; I would set a devil at her elbow in the very church, I would kill her as she gave away her hand.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Wilt help me to a fit circle to play the devil in?

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: I'll place thee, I'll put thy foot into the stirrup.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: And I will rid the world of one of his diseases, a loose woman.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Farewell, eat her very heart. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: As we feed one upon another, hungerly —
sp.stage: Hoboys: enter two friars setting out an altar, enter Jago, Alphonso, Gazetto, Malevento, two churchmen, Tormiella next and the King, ladies attending, Cordolente steals in, and stands in some by place, the King stays or sits in a chair, Tormiella is brought to him, as she is coming the King meets her; as the ring is putting on, Cordolente steps in rudely, breaks them off, Tormiella flies to his bosom, the King offers to stab him, is held: she kneels, sues, weeps, Cordolente is thrust out, Gazetto laughs at all, they are preparing to it again, it thunders and lightens: all affrightedly — exeunt.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p:
Dost thou tell me of thy proclamations that I am banished from the court, that court where I came to thee, was none of thine, it belongs to a King that keeps open court, one
that never wronged a poor beggar, never took away any man's wife, unless he sent his pursuivant death for her: o thou daring sacrilegious royal thief; wilt thou rob the church too, as thou hast me! thrust me out of that house too in the sanctuary, turned devil in a crowd of angels!

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Why didst not kill her?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I had no power to kill her
Charms of divinity pulled back mine arm,
She had armour of proof on, (Reverence of the place)
She is not married, is she, shorten my pains;

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Heaven came itself down, and forbade the banes.

sp.speaker: Jag.
sp.l: You must both to th' King.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Must! we are for him.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Now do I look for a fig.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Chew none, fear nothing.
sp.stage: Flourish. Enter King, Tormiella, Valasco, Malevento, Alphonso.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Has heaven left chiding yet! there's in thy voice
A thunder that worse frights me, didst thou swear
In bed to kill me, had I married thee?

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: It was my vow to do so.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And did that villain,
That Lupo Vindicado's, thrust this vengeance
Into thy desperate hand?

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: That villain swore me
To speed you, I had died else; me had he murdered,
When in a doctor's shape he came to cure
The madness which in me was counterfeit,
Only to shun-your touches.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Strange preservation!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Here comes the traitor!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Devil, didst thou tempt this woman 'gainst my life?

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Has she betrayed me, yes, hence antic vizors
I'll now appear myself.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Gazetto!

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: The same.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I ha' warmed a snake in my bosom.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: This is he,
To whom by promise of my mouth, (Not hers)
Tormiella should ha' been married, but flying him
To run away with this, he in disguise
Has followed both thus long to be revenged.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: And were not my hands tied by your prevention:
It should go forward yet, my plot lay there
(King) to have her kill thee; this cuckold her,
Then had I made him hawks-meat.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Bloody varlet.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Rare providence, I thank thee, what a heap
Of mischiefs have I brought upon my kingdom,
By one base act of lust, and my greatest horror
Is that for her I made away my Queen
By this destroyer's hand, this crimson hellhound
That laughs at nothing but fresh villainies.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: The laughing days I wished for, are now come sir
I am glad that leaping into such a gulf,
I am not drowned, your Queen lives.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: She lives; I had no reason to kill her.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: A better spirit
Stood at his elbow, than you planted there,
My poor girl your sad Queen, breathes yet.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Long may she,
Fetch her, commend me to her, cheer her (Father.)

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: With the best heart I have.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Let that sly bawd
Engine of hell, who wrought upon thy chastity
Be whipped through Seville, four such tempting witches
may undo a city come, you wronged pair
By a King that parted you, you new married are.
Enjoy each other and prosper.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I do already,
Feeling more joys than on my wedding day,
I never till now was married.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Nor I ever happy until this hour.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Nor I, as I am true lord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No sir, you're no true lord, you have a title,
A face of honour, as in courts many have,
For base and servile prostitutions,
And you are such a one, your daughter's fall
Was first step to your rising, and her rising
Again to that sweet goodness she never went from,
Must be your fall, and strip you of all honours
Your lordship is departed.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Does the bell ring out! I care not
sp.p: Your kingdom was a departing too, I had a place in court for nothing, and if it be gone, I can lose nothing; I ha' been like a lord in a play, and that done, my part ends.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Yes sir, I purge my court of such infection.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I shall find-company i'th city I warrant; I am not the first hath given up my cloak of honour.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O my abused heart, thy pardon, see
I have sent home my stolen goods:

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Honestly!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: As she was ever; now with full clear eyes
I see thy beauty, and strange cheeks despise.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: You call me from a grave of shame and sorrow.
In which I lay deep buried.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: From a grave likewise
Your majesty calls me, I have looked back
on all my poor ambitions, and am sorry,
That I fell ever from so bright a sphere,
As is the love of such a royal brother.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Be as you speak, we are friends, it was our will
To let you know, we can, or save, on kill.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Your mercy new transforms me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Sirrah your saving
My Queen, when I confess (Lust me so blinded)
I would have gladly lost her; gives thee life.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: First I thank heaven, then him, and at last you.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: I had not the heart to hurt a woman, if I had, your little face had been malled ere this, but my anger's out, forgive me.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Pray noble brother love this man, he's honest,
I ha' made of him good proof, we should have had
A wedding, but heaven frowned at it, and I
Am glad 'tis crossed, yet we'll both feast and dance,
Our fame hath all this while lain in a trance:
Come Tormiella, well were that city blessed,
That with but, two such women should excel,
But there's so few good, thou'st no parallel.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
